title: Govt Tells Indian Tourists To Be Cautious While Travelling To Turkey Amid Attacks Of Kurds

Govt Tells Indian Tourists To Be Cautious While Travelling To Turkey Amid Attacks Of Kurds

Govt Tells Indian Tourists To Be Cautious While Travelling To Turkey Amid Attacks Of Kurds

The Ministry of External Affairs (MEA) has issued an advisory to Indians on travelling to Turkey which is currently involved in a military offensive in neighboring Syria against the Kurds.

“Although there have been no reports of the untoward incident in the country so far, involving Indian nationals, travelers are required to exercise utmost caution while traveling to Turkey,” the advisory said.

AP

The Indian Mission in Turkey has also put out helpline numbers of the Indian Mission in Ankara and Istanbul for travelers requiring assistance.

Don't Miss 143 SHARES 6.5 K SHARES 2.5 K SHARES 3.9 K SHARES 5.1 K SHARES

The helpline numbers included the Indian Embassy in Ankara (90312-4408259, 90312-4382195) and Consulate General of Istanbul (90212-2962131, 90312-4382195).

Turkey has been a favorite destination for Indian tourists and in the first six months of 2019, some 130,000 Indians had visited the country.

The advisory comes at a time when Turkey is facing international criticism over its military action in Syria, targeting the Kurdish forces. The Kurds who were until recently fighting along with the US troops against ISIS were left to fend themselves after US President Donald Trump announced the withdrawal of American troops from the Syrian-Turkish border.

AFP

Turkish President Recep Tayyip Erdogan was quick to launch an offensive against the Kurds whom Ankara views as an extension of the PKK which is declared a terrorist organization by Turkey.

The development also comes days after India postponed the upcoming visit of Prime Minister Narendra Modi to Ankara over Erdogan's comment on Kashmir.

AFP/ FILE

Speaking at the UN in August Erdogan had urged India to hold talks with Pakistan Kashmir.

There are also reports that Ankara's 45,000-ton fleet support ships (FSS) deal for the Indian Navy, estimated to cost $2.3 billion, was expected to be put on hold over the comment.
